title: Sex Determination in a Lizard Species

content.question:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

The sex of an organism is typically determined genetically, but environmental factors can also play a role. Scientists examined the roles of genes and environmental temperature in the sex determination of a lizard species. Individuals with a <math alttext="Z W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> pair of chromosomes are always female (<math alttext="Z W f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZWf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), while individuals with a <math alttext="Z Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> pair of chromosomes can be either male (<math alttext="Z Z m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) or female (<math alttext="Z Z f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Scientists mated <math alttext="Z W f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZWf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="Z Z f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> females with <math alttext="Z Z m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> males and incubated the eggs produced in 20 clutches at temperatures ranging from <math alttext="23 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>23</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="36 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>36</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. When the young hatched, the scientists determined their sexes (Table 1). Among the eggs that did not hatch, the mortality of embryonic lizards was approximately the same for both males and females.

Table 1. Fraction of female progeny produced as a function of egg incubation temperatureEgg Incubation Temperature (<math alttext="degrees Celsius" display="inline" depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>ZWf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Crosses: Fraction of Female Progeny (a) If a particular gene is located on the <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome of this lizard species, describe why a lizard with a <math alttext="Z W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> genotype has a greater probability of expressing the recessive phenotype for the trait than a lizard with the <math alttext="Z Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> genotype does.

The sex of an organism is typically determined genetically, but environmental factors can also play a role. Scientists examined the roles of genes and environmental temperature in the sex determination of a lizard species. Individuals with a <math alttext="Z W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> pair of chromosomes are always female (<math alttext="Z W f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZWf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), while individuals with a <math alttext="Z Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> pair of chromosomes can be either male (<math alttext="Z Z m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) or female (<math alttext="Z Z f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). When the young hatched, the scientists determined their sexes (Table 1). Among the eggs that did not hatch, the mortality of embryonic lizards was approximately the same for both males and females.

overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.0 plus or minus 0.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> 

(a) If a particular gene is located on the <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome of this lizard species, describe why a lizard with a <math alttext="Z W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> genotype has a greater probability of expressing the recessive phenotype for the trait than a lizard with the <math alttext="Z Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> genotype does.

(b) Using the template, construct an appropriately labeled graph, including error bars, to represent the data in Table 1. Based on the data, compare the <math alttext="Z Z m by Z W f"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZm</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>ZWf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> crosses and the <math alttext="Z Z m by Z Z f"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ZZm</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>ZZf</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> crosses to determine whether there is a significant difference between the two crosses in the fraction of female progeny produced at <math alttext="24 degrees Celsius "><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="32 degrees Celsius"><mstyle><mrow><mn>32</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="36 degrees Celsius"><mstyle><mrow><mn>36</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) For each cross, describe whether genetics or temperature determines the sex of progeny produced from eggs incubated at <math alttext="35 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. For each cross, describe whether genetics or temperature determines the sex of progeny produced from eggs incubated at <math alttext="24 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Predict the effect of increasing global temperatures on the continued presence of the <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome in this species of lizard. Scientists claim that, in this species, the <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome is unimportant in sex determination. Instead, proteins that are encoded by a gene or genes on the <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> chromosome, and that are maximally expressed only at certain temperatures, are responsible for determining whether embryos will develop as females or males. Use the data to support this claim.
